subject: Modify set-value function from external
commitMessage:
Modify set-value function from external

    Move Special mode from bmcweb to dbus-sensors, this will be handled via dbus-sensor when the user set-value f$
    This is unlikely to break any users because the Intel special mode function is no change, only move to dbus-s$

    The set value function is to filter the external set, excluding the internal set.
    In the external set, if in INSECURE_UNRESTRICTED_SENSOR_OVERRIDE, no need to check before set value else add $

    bmcweb needs to be merged at the same time.
    bmcweb changes are pushed to Gerrit:
    https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/42448

    the mailing list discussion links:
    https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2021-March/025597.html

Signed-off-by: Bruce Lee <Bruce_Lee@quantatw.com>
Change-Id: I0919e4d2343e81045010a2b0d4bf01dc272bcb07

Patch Set 22:

I had a similar solution, adding the "Mutable" value to the object. The "Mutable" field would be a bool, like the old "Mutability" flag in the old hardcoded YAML sensors configuration. It would let external services, like IPMI and Redfish, know whether or not to allow external users to mutate the sensor value (i.e. read-write instead of read-only permissions on it).
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/36275

Change has been successfully merged by Ed Tanous

I thought we allow external sensor override for PWM sensors and external sensors in normal model. Should it be something like

```
bool settable = false;

#ifdef BMCWEB_INSECURE_UNRESTRICTED_SENSOR_OVERRIDE
  settable = true
#else
  settable = isSpecialMode() || isExtenalSensor()
```
modified
Please base this on information in the sensor classes themselves.
modified as suggested
Is it possible to reuse the dbus and use async calls to keep the style consistent?
+1.  Please don't open up yet another bus connection just to use this.
modified as suggested

?  Why does this code need to exist.  ExternalSensor is determined by code in this repo.  Just have ExternalSensor skip the check, and other sensors keep the check.  THere's no need to ask the mapper.
modified as suggested
Please wrap your commit message lines 50/72
modified as suggested
More details needed here.  Please include the expected changes in behavior, and any patches that need to be merged at the same time.
modified as suggested
nit: indent

If I do not do this jenkins will show an error and build failed.
https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/16068/console
I saw these are removed out of bmcweb with linked Gerrit review. How are these beging set now?

That's a good catch. These definitions are supposed to become part of dbus-sensors now. I guess we missed some meson options. 

Bruce, can we add these definition as meson options like what currently BMCWeb is doing?

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/meson_options.txt#L44
modified as suggested.

I would really like to see this using a config file from meson similar to https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/15c27bf8ea1f7e2f8e07d1eaf386466091d69c17/meson.build#L357

With a regular if (variable) statement to enable this functionality.  I know you copied this from bmcweb, but this was found to be somewhat of an anti-pattern there, so I'd like to no propogate it further.
Modified as suggested.

Please don't hardcode specific instances of a sensor like this in something designed to be generic.

Please make the sensor side of this generic, with something like "is sensor settable" that the parent class can set;  ExternalSensor can then make this value settable.
Modified as suggested.
it seems like the code would be cleaner if, for all the places we set settable = false, we instead just directly threw the exception.
Modified as suggested.
This is going to cause performance problems by requiring a dbus call on every set.  I suspect we need to have a match expression.
Modified as suggested.
This is a blocking call in an async daemon.  please use async_method_call.
if use the use async_method_call then we can not get the return value to check special mode is enable or not. Could you give some advice for this situation and resolve it.
if we do not throw an Exception to bmcweb to let bmcweb know set success or fail, so I think use async_method_call will not be a  problem.
Modified as suggested.
Check for validity before dereferencing.
Modified as suggested.
This check isn't really needed.  It's roughly covered in the next async_method_call, which will fail.
Modified as suggested.
Another blocking dbus call.
Modified as suggested.
Check also not needed.
Modified as suggested.
nit, load the result of this into a boolean, and return it directly.  That removes the need for separate "return true" and "return false" statements.
Modified as suggested.
Please remove this.  We don't want to print this on every set.
Modified as suggested.
nit: not sure whether we want use BMCWEB in the macro name here
Modified as suggested.
nit, technically this isn't intel specific, right?  (although I think they're the only platform that implements it)
Remove Intel
Should this be set10?  similar to here: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/1b1be67fb8d50293d452316f51227363750a3d00/meson.build#L355
Modified

This is already default to false, so it does not have to be in the constructor. The two special case can set it to true in the constructor. That way we avoid increasing the already long parameter list for the constructor.

Does it make more sense to make this an enum class instead of a bool?

SensorType::Writable seems a lot more readable than just "true"

> This is already default to false, so it does not have to be in the constructor. The two special case can set it to true in the constructor. 

Please don't do that, as it puts sensor-specific data into the generic sensor class (we'd have to match on interface name like the first patch did)

> That way we avoid increasing the already long parameter list for the constructor.

Agreed, this is already long, but I don't see how we avoid it in this case.  At some point the init params probably need to become their own struct.




With all that said, agree, this = false is redundant and can be removed.
Done
should be 0
Modified.
please don't do blocking calls in an async daemon.  use async_method_call.
Modified.

This has a race condition if the daemon that publishes xyz.openbmc_project.Security.SpecialMode hasn't started when this is run.

You need to remove this from the getsubtree check, and make sure it's instantiated before you do the mapper call.

Modified.
follow origin design, if the specialMode interface exist, then check the subtree information.
If other user need to use the specialMode service in their project, they should add the After to wait specialMode service ready before start dbus-sensor.

> Modified.
> follow origin design, if the specialMode interface exist, then check the subtree information.
> If other user need to use the specialMode service in their project, they should add the After to wait specialMode service ready before start dbus-sensor.

That goes against the design of dbus-sensors, but was fine in bmcweb, because we were doing it in the context of a low-rate set request.  in dbus-sensors, all of these are high rate.  At one point dbus-sensors did what you recommended and relied on the AFTER param, but had issues with reliability and handling service restarts, hence why the design today is different.
Could advise how to implement to support the "make sure it's instantiated before you do the mapper call"?

Move the match expression to a different context (probably somewhere in main), and have it set a variable in the application state that tracks whether or not manufacturing mode is enabled.  Then reference that variable later.
Remove the getsubtree check, only keep the match expression, when the service starts it will register the propertiesChanged to monitor and change the variable value when getting the change signal.
missing length check.  You need to loop over propertiesChanged
Modified

you need to actually check the value here.  this will enable SP mode for ANY property change, whether enabled or disabled.

Also, because you have two interfaces you need to track, I suspect you need two variables here.
Not really understand what you mean, I reference https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/sensors.hpp#L2942 to modified, what two interfaces need to track?
Does this still an issue "two interfaces you need to track, I suspect you need two variables here."? or it can match the requirement after removing the getsubtree check.
Hi Ed, do you still have concerns here? I don't fully understand your comment as well. Seems like we are doing the correct thing by performing string comparison.
should there be isSpModeEnable = false for the "else" case?

I reference https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/sensors.hpp#L2942
the else is default value isSpModeEnable = false;
Please be more specific about what exceptions you are catching here.
Modified.
If we fail we destroy the match entirely?  that doesn't seem right.
Modified.
nit: not needed
Modified.
also not needed.
Modified.
nit: can we name this "setupManufacturingModeMatch" to make it more clear?
Modified
bool?

I look at https://mesonbuild.com/Configuration.html and use set10 to define a boolean value.
"Often you have a boolean value in Meson but need to define the C/C++ token as 0 or 1. Meson provides a convenience function for this use case."
Modified as suggested.
Same as above.  Bool?

I look at https://mesonbuild.com/Configuration.html and use set10 to define a boolean value.
"Often you have a boolean value in Meson but need to define the C/C++ token as 0 or 1. Meson provides a convenience function for this use case."

Can we split this up a little to make it more clear.

Having a separate condition for each "failed to set" type seems useful.
Modified.
This method doesn't need to take ownership of the connection, so this method argument should just be sdbusplus::asio::connection&
Modified.
